cleaned_text: Vaccine hesitancy |Part of |[Vaccination](/wiki/Vaccination) |This article is part of |[Alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) Vaccine hesitancy is a delay in acceptance, or refusal, of [vaccines](/wiki/Vaccine) despite the availability of vaccine services and supporting evidence. The term covers refusals to vaccinate, delaying vaccines, accepting vaccines but remaining uncertain about their use, or using certain vaccines but not others. [[1]](#cite_note-1) [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) [[3]](#cite_note-Larson2014-3) [[4]](#cite_note-4) The [scientific consensus](/wiki/Scientific_consensus) that vaccines and effective is overwhelming. [[5]](#cite_note-5) [[6]](#cite_note-6) [[7]](#cite_note-7) [[8]](#cite_note-8) Vaccine hesitancy often results Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) characterizes vaccine hesitancy as one of the top ten global health threats. [[15]](#cite_note-15) [[16]](#cite_note-16) "Anti-vaccinationism" refers to total opposition to vaccination; in more recent years, anti-vaccinationists have been known as "anti-vaxxers" or "anti-vax". [[17]](#cite_note-17) Vaccine hesitancy is complex and context-specific, varying across time, place and vaccines. [[18]](#cite_note-18) It can be influenced by factors such as lack of proper scientifically based knowledge and understanding about how vaccines are made or work, as well as psychological factors including [fear of needles](/wiki/Fear_of_needles) [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) and distrust of public authorities, a person's lack of confidence (mistrust of the vaccine and/or healthcare provider), complacency (the person does not see a need for the vaccine or does not see the value of the vaccine), and convenience (access to vaccines). [[3]](#cite_note-Larson2014-3) It has existed since the invention of vaccination and pre-dates the coining of the terms "vaccine" and "vaccination" by nearly eighty years. The specific hypotheses raised by anti-vaccination advocates have been found to change over time. [[19]](#cite_note-Gerber-19) Although myths, [conspiracy theories](/wiki/Conspiracy_theory), [misinformation](/wiki/Misinformation_related_to_vaccination) and [disinformation](/wiki/Disinformation_attack) spread by the anti-vaccination movement and [fringe](/wiki/Fringe_science) doctors leads to vaccine hesitancy and public debates around the medical, ethical, and legal issues related to vaccines, there is no serious hesitancy or debate within mainstream medical and scientific circles about the benefits of vaccination. [[20]](#cite_note-Dubé-20) Proposed laws that mandate vaccination, such as [California Senate Bill 277](/wiki/California_Senate_Bill_277) and Australia's [No Jab No Pay](/wiki/No_Jab_No_Pay), organizations](/wiki/List_of_anti-vaccination_groups). [[21]](#cite_note-21) [[22]](#cite_note-22) [[23]](#cite_note-23) Opposition to [mandatory vaccination](/wiki/Vaccine_policy) may be on anti-vaccine sentiment, concern that it violates [civil liberties](/wiki/Civil_liberties) or reduces public trust in vaccination, or suspicion of profiteering by the pharmaceutical industry. [[11]](#cite_note-wolfesharp-11) [[24]](#cite_note-24) [[25]](#cite_note-25) [[26]](#cite_note-26) [[27]](#cite_note-27) Effectiveness Scientific evidence for the effectiveness of large-scale vaccination campaigns is well established. [[28]](#cite_note-28) Two to three million deaths are prevented each year worldwide by vaccination, and an additional 1.5 million deaths could be prevented each year if all recommended vaccines were used. [[29]](#cite_note-Jacobson2020-29) Vaccination campaigns helped eradicate [smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox), which once killed as many as one in seven children in Europe, [[30]](#cite_note-Fenner-30) and have nearly [eradicated polio](/wiki/Poliomyelitis_eradication). [[31]](#cite_note-31) As a more modest example, infections caused by [Haemophilus influenzae](/wiki/Haemophilus_influenzae) (Hib), a major cause of [bacterial meningitis](/wiki/Bacterial_meningitis) and other serious diseases in children, have decreased by over 99% in the US since the introduction of a vaccine in 1988. [[32]](#cite_note-32) It is estimated that full vaccination, from birth to adolescence, of all US children born in a given year would save 33,000 lives and prevent 14 million infections. [[33]](#cite_note-33) There is anti-vaccine literature that argues that reductions in infectious disease result from improved sanitation and hygiene (rather than vaccination) or that these diseases were already in decline before the introduction of specific vaccines. These claims are not supported by scientific data; the incidence of vaccine-preventable diseases tended to fluctuate over time until the introduction of specific vaccines, at which point the incidence dropped to near zero. A [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) website aimed at countering common misconceptions about vaccines argued, "Are we expected to believe that better sanitation caused the incidence of each disease to drop, just at the time a vaccine for that disease was introduced?" [[34]](#cite_note-CDC:_common_misconceptions-34) Another rallying cry of the anti-vaccine movement is to call for randomized [clinical trials](/wiki/Clinical_trials) in which an experimental group of children are vaccinated while a [control group](/wiki/Control_group) are unvaccinated. Such a study would never be approved because it would require deliberately denying children standard medical care, rendering the study unethical. Studies have been done that compare vaccinated to unvaccinated people, but the studies are typically not randomized. Moreover, literature already exists that demonstrates the safety of vaccines using other experimental methods. [[35]](#cite_note-35) Other critics argue that the immunity granted by vaccines is only temporary and requires boosters, whereas those who survive the disease become permanently immune. [[11]](#cite_note-wolfesharp-11) As discussed below, the philosophies of some [alternative medicine](#Alternative_medicine) practitioners are incompatible with the idea that vaccines are effective. [[36]](#cite_note-Ernst-36) Population health Incomplete vaccine coverage increases the risk of disease for the entire population, including those who have been vaccinated, because it reduces [herd immunity](/wiki/Herd_immunity). For example, the measles vaccine is given to children 9-12 months old, and the window between the disappearance of maternal antibody and [seroconversion](/wiki/Seroconversion) means that vaccinated children are frequently still vulnerable. Strong herd immunity reduces this vulnerability. Increasing herd immunity during an outbreak or when there is a risk of an outbreak is perhaps the most widely accepted justification for mass vaccination. When a new vaccine is introduced, mass vaccination can help increase coverage rapidly. [[40]](#cite_note-40) If enough of a population is vaccinated, herd immunity takes effect, decreasing risk to people who cannot receive vaccines because they are too young or old, immunocompromised, or have severe allergies to the ingredients in the vaccine. [[41]](#cite_note-41) The outcome for people with compromised immune systems who get infected is often worse than that of the general population. [[42]](#cite_note-42) Cost-effectiveness Commonly used vaccines are a cost-effective and preventive way of promoting health, compared to the treatment of acute or chronic disease. In 2001, the United States spent approximately $2.8 billion to promote and implement routine [childhood immunizations](/wiki/Vaccination_schedule) against seven diseases. The societal benefits of those vaccinations were estimated to be $46.6 billion, yielding a benefit-cost ratio of 16.5. [[43]](#cite_note-43) Necessity When a vaccination program successfully reduces the disease threat, it may reduce the perceived risk of disease as cultural memories of the effects of that disease fade. At this point, parents may feel they have nothing to lose by not vaccinating their children. [[44]](#cite_note-44) If enough people hope to become [free-riders](/wiki/Free_rider_problem), gaining the benefits of herd immunity without vaccination, vaccination levels may drop to a level where herd immunity is ineffective. [[45]](#cite_note-45) According to [Jennifer Reich](/wiki/Jennifer_Reich), those parents who believe vaccination to be quite effective but might prefer their children to remain unvaccinated, are those who are the most likely to be convinced to change their mind, as long as they are approached properly. [[46]](#cite_note-46) Safety concerns While some anti-vaccinationists openly deny the improvements vaccination has made to public health or believe in [conspiracy theories](/wiki/Conspiracy_theories), [[11]](#cite_note-wolfesharp-11) it is much more common to cite concerns about safety. [[47]](#cite_note-LancetID-47) As with any medical treatment, there is a potential for vaccines to cause serious complications, such as severe allergic reactions, [[48]](#cite_note-48) but unlike most other medical interventions, vaccines are given to healthy people and so a higher standard of safety is demanded. [[49]](#cite_note-49) While serious complications from vaccinations are possible, they are extremely rare and much less common than similar risks from the diseases they prevent. [[34]](#cite_note-CDC:_common_misconceptions-34) As the success of immunization programs increases and the incidence of disease decreases, public attention shifts away from the risks of disease to the risk of vaccination, [[50]](#cite_note-BH-50) and it becomes challenging for health authorities to preserve public support for vaccination programs. [[51]](#cite_note-51) The overwhelming success of certain vaccinations has made certain diseases rare, and, consequently, has led to incorrect [heuristic thinking](/wiki/Heuristics_in_judgment_and_decision-making) in weighing risks against benefits among people who are vaccine-hesitant. [[52]](#cite_note-Jacobson2015-52) Once such diseases (e.g., [Haemophilus influenzae B](/wiki/Haemophilus_influenzae_serotype_b)) decrease in prevalence, people may no longer appreciate how serious the illness is due to a lack of familiarity with it and become complacent. [[52]](#cite_note-Jacobson2015-52) The lack of personal experience with these diseases reduces the perceived danger and thus reduces the perceived benefit of immunization. [[53]](#cite_note-Marshall2013-53) Conversely, certain illnesses (e.g., [influenza](/wiki/Influenza)) remain so common that vaccine-hesitant people mistakenly perceive the illness to be non-threatening despite clear evidence that the illness poses a significant threat to human health. [[52]](#cite_note-Jacobson2015-52) [Omission](/wiki/Omission_bias) and [disconfirmation biases](/wiki/Disconfirmation_bias) also contribute to vaccine hesitancy. [[52]](#cite_note-Jacobson2015-52) [[54]](#cite_note-McClure2017-54) Various concerns about immunization have been raised. They have been addressed and the concerns are not supported by evidence. [[53]](#cite_note-Marshall2013-53) Concerns about immunization safety often follow a pattern. First, some investigators suggest that a medical condition of increasing prevalence or unknown cause is an adverse effect of vaccination. The initial study and subsequent studies by the same group have an inadequate methodology, typically a poorly controlled or uncontrolled [case series](/wiki/Case_series). A premature announcement is made about the alleged adverse effect, resonating with individuals who have the condition, and underestimating the potential harm of forgoing vaccination to those whom the vaccine could protect. Other groups attempt to replicate the initial study but fail to get the same results. Finally, it takes several years to regain public confidence in the vaccine. [[50]](#cite_note-BH-50) Adverse effects ascribed to vaccines typically have an unknown origin, an increasing [incidence](/wiki/Incidence_(epidemiology)), some [biological plausibility](/wiki/Biological_plausibility), occurrences close to the time of vaccination, and dreaded outcomes. [[55]](#cite_note-55) In almost all cases, the public health effect is limited by cultural boundaries: English speakers worry about one vaccine causing [autism](/wiki/Autism), while French speakers worry about another vaccine causing multiple sclerosis, and Nigerians worry that a third vaccine causes infertility. [[56]](#cite_note-56) Thiomersal [Thiomersal](/wiki/Thiomersal) (called "thimerosal" in the US) is an [antifungal](/wiki/Antifungal) preservative used in small amounts in some multi-dose vaccines (where the same vial is opened and used for multiple patients) to prevent contamination of the vaccine. [[57]](#cite_note-Baker-57) Despite thiomersal's efficacy, the use of thiomersal is controversial because it can be metabolized or degraded in the body to [ethylmercury](/wiki/Ethylmercury) (C2H5Hg+) and [thiosalicylate](/wiki/Thiosalicylate). [[58]](#cite_note-T-in-vaccines-58) [[59]](#cite_note-cber2019-59) As a result, in 1999, the [Centers for Disease Control](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) (CDC) and the [American Academy of Pediatrics](/wiki/American_Academy_of_Pediatrics) (AAP) asked vaccine makers to remove thiomersal from vaccines as quickly as possible on the [precautionary principle](/wiki/Precautionary_principle). Thiomersal is now absent from all common US and European vaccines, except for some preparations of [influenza vaccine](/wiki/Influenza_vaccine). [[60]](#cite_note-Offit-60) Trace amounts remain in some vaccines due to production processes, at an approximate maximum of one microgramme, around 15% of the average daily mercury intake in the US for adults and 2.5% of the daily level considered tolerable by the [WHO](/wiki/World_Health_Organization). [[59]](#cite_note-cber2019-59) [[61]](#cite_note-61) The action sparked concern that thiomersal could have been responsible for autism. [[60]](#cite_note-Offit-60) The idea is now considered disproven, as incidence rates for autism increased steadily even after thiomersal was removed from childhood vaccines. [[19]](#cite_note-Gerber-19) Currently there is no accepted scientific evidence that exposure to thiomersal is a factor in causing autism. [[62]](#cite_note-62) [[63]](#cite_note-Spencer2017-63) Since 2000, parents in the United States have pursued legal compensation from a federal fund arguing that thiomersal caused autism in their children. [[64]](#cite_note-Sugarman-64) A 2004 [Institute of Medicine](/wiki/Institute_of_Medicine) (IOM) committee favored rejecting any causal relationship between thiomersal-containing vaccines and autism. [[65]](#cite_note-ISRC-65) The concentration of thiomersal used in vaccines as an antimicrobial agent ranges from 0.001% (1 part in 100,000) to 0.01% (1 part in 10,000). [[66]](#cite_note-FDAThiomersalTuna-66) A vaccine containing 0.01% thiomersal has 25 micrograms of mercury per 0.5 mL dose, roughly the same amount of elemental mercury found in a three-ounce (85 g) can of [tuna](/wiki/Tuna). [[66]](#cite_note-FDAThiomersalTuna-66) There is robust peer-reviewed scientific evidence supporting the safety of thiomersal-containing vaccines. [[66]](#cite_note-FDAThiomersalTuna-66) MMR vaccine In the UK, the [MMR vaccine](/wiki/MMR_vaccine) was the subject of controversy after the publication in [The Lancet](/wiki/The_Lancet) of a 1998 paper by [Andrew Wakefield](/wiki/Andrew_Wakefield) and others reporting case histories of twelve children mostly with [autism spectrum disorders](/wiki/Autism_spectrum) with onset soon after administration of the vaccine. [[67]](#cite_note-67) At a 1998 press conference, Wakefield suggested that giving children the vaccines in three separate doses would be safer than a single vaccination. This suggestion was not supported by the paper, and several subsequent peer-reviewed studies have failed to show any association between the vaccine and autism. [[68]](#cite_note-NHS-68) It later emerged that Wakefield had received funding from litigants against vaccine manufacturers and that he had not informed colleagues or medical authorities of his [conflict of interest](/wiki/Conflict_of_interest): Wakefield reportedly stood to earn up to $43 million per year selling diagnostic kits. [[69]](#cite_note-WakefieldCapitalize-69) [[70]](#cite_note-70) Had this been known, publication in The Lancet would not have taken place in the way that it did. [[71]](#cite_note-71) Wakefield has been heavily criticized on scientific and ethical grounds for the way the research was conducted [[72]](#cite_note-paid_children-72) and for triggering a decline in vaccination rates, which fell in the UK to 80% in the years following the study. [[73]](#cite_note-73) [[74]](#cite_note-Alazraki11-74) In 2004, the MMR-and-autism interpretation of the paper was formally retracted by ten of its thirteen coauthors, [[75]](#cite_note-75) and in 2010 The Lancet's editors fully retracted the paper. [[76]](#cite_note-76) [[77]](#cite_note-Triggle_2/2/2010-77) Wakefield was struck off the [UK medical register](/wiki/General_Medical_Council#Registering_doctors_in_the_UK), with a statement identifying deliberate falsification in the research published in The Lancet, [[78]](#cite_note-gmc-uk_Wakefield_SPM-78) and is barred from practicing medicine in the UK. [[79]](#cite_note-MeikleBoseley-79) The CDC, the IOM of the [National Academy of Sciences](/wiki/United_States_National_Academy_of_Sciences), Australia's [Department of Health](/wiki/Department_of_Health_(Australia)), and the UK [National Health Service](/wiki/National_Health_Service) have all concluded that there is no evidence of a link between the MMR vaccine and autism. [[65]](#cite_note-ISRC-65) [[80]](#cite_note-80) [[81]](#cite_note-81) [[82]](#cite_note-AustraliaVaccines-82) A [Cochrane review](/wiki/Cochrane_review) concluded that there is no credible link between the MMR vaccine and autism, that MMR has prevented diseases that still carry a heavy burden of death and complications, that the lack of confidence in MMR has damaged public health, and that the design and reporting of safety outcomes in MMR vaccine studies are largely inadequate. [[83]](#cite_note-pmid22336803-83) Additional reviews agree, with studies finding that vaccines are not linked to autism even in high risk populations with autistic siblings. [[84]](#cite_note-84) In 2009, [The Sunday Times](/wiki/The_Sunday_Times) reported that Wakefield had manipulated patient data and misreported results in his 1998 paper, creating the appearance of a link with autism. [[85]](#cite_note-85) A 2011 article in the [British Medical Journal](/wiki/BMJ) described how the data in the study had been falsified by Wakefield so that it would arrive at a predetermined conclusion. [[86]](#cite_note-86) An accompanying editorial in the same journal described Wakefield's work as an "elaborate [fraud](/wiki/Fraud)" that led to lower vaccination rates, putting hundreds of thousands of children at risk and diverting energy and money away from research into the true cause of autism. [[87]](#cite_note-87) A special court convened in the United States to review claims under the [National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program](/wiki/Vaccine_court) ruled on February 12, 2009, that the evidence "failed to demonstrate that thimerosal-containing vaccines can contribute to causing immune dysfunction, or that the MMR vaccine can contribute to causing either autism or gastrointestinal dysfunction", and that parents of autistic children were therefore not entitled to compensation in their contention that certain vaccines caused autism in their children. [[88]](#cite_note-88) Vaccine overload Vaccine overload, a non-medical term, is the notion that giving many vaccines at once may overwhelm or weaken a child's immature immune system and lead to adverse effects. [[89]](#cite_note-Hilton-89) Despite scientific evidence that strongly contradicts this idea, [[19]](#cite_note-Gerber-19) there are still parents of autistic children that believe that vaccine overload causes autism. [[90]](#cite_note-90) The resulting controversy has caused many parents to delay or avoid immunizing their children. [[89]](#cite_note-Hilton-89) Such parental misperceptions are major obstacles towards immunization of children. [[91]](#cite_note-91) The concept of vaccine overload is flawed on several levels. [[19]](#cite_note-Gerber-19) Despite the increase in the number of vaccines over recent decades, improvements in vaccine design have reduced the immunologic load from vaccines; the total number of immunological components in the 14 vaccines administered to US children in 2009 is less than ten percent of what it was in the seven vaccines given in 1980. [[19]](#cite_note-Gerber-19) A study published in 2013 found no correlation between autism and the [antigen](/wiki/Antigen) number in the vaccines the children were administered up to the age of two. There were 1,008 children in the study, one quarter of whom were diagnosed with autism, and the whole cohort was born between 1994 and 1999, when the routine vaccine schedule could contain more than 3,000 antigens (in a single shot of [DTP vaccine](/wiki/DTP_vaccine)). The vaccine schedule in 2012 contains several more vaccines, but the number of antigens the child is exposed to by the age of two is 315. [[92]](#cite_note-92) [[93]](#cite_note-93) Vaccines pose a very small immunologic load compared to the pathogens naturally encountered by a child in a typical year; [[19]](#cite_note-Gerber-19) common childhood conditions such as fevers and [middle-ear infections](/wiki/Otitis_media) pose a much greater challenge to the immune system than vaccines, [[94]](#cite_note-94) and studies have shown that vaccinations, even multiple concurrent vaccinations, do not weaken the immune system [[19]](#cite_note-Gerber-19) or compromise overall immunity. [[95]](#cite_note-95) The lack of evidence supporting the vaccine overload hypothesis, combined with these findings directly contradicting it, has led to the conclusion that currently recommended vaccine programs do not "overload" or weaken the immune system. [[50]](#cite_note-BH-50) [[96]](#cite_note-96) [[97]](#cite_note-Hackett-Offit-97) [[98]](#cite_note-Schneeweiss-98) Any experiment based on withholding vaccines from children is considered unethical, [[99]](#cite_note-99) and observational studies would likely be [confounded](/wiki/Confounding) by differences in the healthcare-seeking behaviors of under-vaccinated children. Thus, no study directly comparing rates of autism in vaccinated and unvaccinated children has been done. However, the concept of vaccine overload is biologically implausible, as vaccinated and unvaccinated children have the same immune response to non-vaccine-related infections, and autism is not an immune-mediated disease, so claims that vaccines could cause it by overloading the immune system go against current knowledge of the [pathogenesis](/wiki/Pathogenesis) of autism. As such, the idea that vaccines cause autism has been effectively dismissed by the weight of current evidence. [[19]](#cite_note-Gerber-19) Prenatal infection There is evidence that [schizophrenia](/wiki/Schizophrenia) is associated with prenatal exposure to [rubella](/wiki/Rubella), [influenza](/wiki/Influenza), and [toxoplasmosis](/wiki/Toxoplasmosis) infection. For example, one study found a sevenfold increased risk of schizophrenia when mothers were exposed to influenza in the first trimester of gestation. This may have public health implications, as strategies for preventing infection include vaccination, simple hygiene, and, in the case of toxoplasmosis, [antibiotics](/wiki/Antibiotic). [[100]](#cite_note-100) Based on studies in animal models, theoretical concerns have been raised about a possible link between schizophrenia and maternal immune response activated by virus antigens; a 2009 review concluded that there was insufficient evidence to recommend routine use of [trivalent influenza vaccine](/wiki/Influenza_vaccine) during the first trimester of pregnancy, but that the vaccine was still recommended outside the first trimester and in special circumstances such as pandemics or in women with certain other conditions. [[101]](#cite_note-101) The CDC's [Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices](/wiki/Advisory_Committee_on_Immunization_Practices), the [American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists](/wiki/American_Congress_of_Obstetricians_and_Gynecologists), and the [American Academy of Family Physicians](/wiki/American_Academy_of_Family_Physicians) all recommend routine flu shots for pregnant women, for several reasons: [[102]](#cite_note-ACIP2007-102) - their risk for serious influenza-related medical complications during the last two trimesters; - their greater rates for flu-related hospitalizations compared to non-pregnant women; - the possible transfer of maternal anti-influenza antibodies to children, protecting the children from the flu; and - several studies that found no harm to pregnant women or their children from the vaccinations. Despite this recommendation, only 16% of healthy pregnant US women surveyed in 2005 had been vaccinated against the flu. [[102]](#cite_note-ACIP2007-102) Ingredient concerns Aluminum compounds are used as [immunologic adjuvants](/wiki/Immunologic_adjuvant) to increase the effectiveness of many vaccines. [[103]](#cite_note-Principi2018-103) The aluminum in vaccines simulates or causes small amounts of tissue damage, driving the body to respond more powerfully to what it sees as a serious infection and promoting the development of a lasting immune response. [[104]](#cite_note-Baylor-104) [[105]](#cite_note-105) In some cases these compounds have been associated with redness, itching, and low-grade fever, [[104]](#cite_note-Baylor-104) but the use of aluminum in vaccines has not been associated with serious adverse events. [[103]](#cite_note-Principi2018-103) [[106]](#cite_note-Francois-106) In some cases, aluminum-containing vaccines are associated with [macrophagic myofasciitis](/wiki/Macrophagic_myofasciitis) (MMF), localized microscopic [lesions](/wiki/Lesion) containing aluminum salts that persist for up to 8 years. However, recent case-controlled studies have found no specific clinical symptoms in individuals with biopsies showing MMF, and there is no evidence that aluminum-containing vaccines are a serious health risk or justify changes to immunization practice. [[103]](#cite_note-Principi2018-103) [[106]](#cite_note-Francois-106) Infants are exposed to greater quantities of aluminum in daily life in breastmilk and infant formula than in vaccines. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) In general, people are exposed to low levels of naturally occurring aluminum in nearly all foods and drinking water. [[107]](#cite_note-OxfordVaccineIngredients-107) The amount of aluminum present in vaccines is small, less than one milligram, and such low levels are not believed to be harmful to human health. [[107]](#cite_note-OxfordVaccineIngredients-107) Vaccine hesitant people have also voiced strong concerns about the presence of [formaldehyde](/wiki/Formaldehyde) in vaccines. Formaldehyde is used in very small concentrations to inactivate viruses and bacterial toxins used in vaccines. [[108]](#cite_note-FDAVaccineIngredient-108) Very small amounts of residual formaldehyde can be present in vaccines but are far below values harmful to human health. [[109]](#cite_note-CHOPformaldehyde-109) [[110]](#cite_note-Vaccineingredients-110) The levels present in vaccines are minuscule when compared to naturally occurring levels of formaldehyde in the human body and pose no significant risk of toxicity. [[108]](#cite_note-FDAVaccineIngredient-108) The human body continuously produces formaldehyde naturally and contains 50-70 times the greatest amount of formaldehyde present in any vaccine. [[108]](#cite_note-FDAVaccineIngredient-108) Furthermore, the human body is capable of breaking down naturally occurring formaldehyde as well as the small amount of formaldehyde present in vaccines. [[108]](#cite_note-FDAVaccineIngredient-108) There is no evidence linking the infrequent exposures to small quantities of formaldehyde present in vaccines with [cancer](/wiki/Cancer). [[108]](#cite_note-FDAVaccineIngredient-108) Sudden infant death syndrome [Sudden infant death syndrome](/wiki/Sudden_infant_death_syndrome) (SIDS) is most common in infants around the time in life when they receive many vaccinations. [[111]](#cite_note-PediatricsSIDS2016-111) Since the cause of SIDS has not been fully determined, this led to concerns about whether vaccines, in particular diphtheria-tetanus toxoid vaccines, were a possible causal factor. [[111]](#cite_note-PediatricsSIDS2016-111) Several studies investigated this and found no evidence supporting a causal link between vaccination and SIDS. [[111]](#cite_note-PediatricsSIDS2016-111) [[112]](#cite_note-2016TaskForceSIDSRecs-112) In 2003, the [Institute of Medicine](/wiki/Institute_of_Medicine) favored rejection of a causal link to [DTwP](/wiki/DTP_vaccine) vaccination and SIDS after reviewing the available evidence. [[113]](#cite_note-113) Additional analyses of [VAERS](/wiki/VAERS) data also showed no relationship between vaccination and SIDS. [[111]](#cite_note-PediatricsSIDS2016-111) Studies have shown a negative correlation between SIDs and vaccination. That is vaccinated children are less likely to die but no causal link has been found. One suggestion is that infants who are less likely to develop SIDS are more likely to be presented for vaccination. [[111]](#cite_note-PediatricsSIDS2016-111) [[112]](#cite_note-2016TaskForceSIDSRecs-112) [[114]](#cite_note-Vennemann2007-114) Anthrax vaccines In the mid-1990s media reports on vaccines discussed the [Gulf War Syndrome](/wiki/Gulf_War_Syndrome), a multi-symptomatic disorder affecting returning US military veterans of the [1990-1991 Persian Gulf War](/wiki/Gulf_War). Among the first articles of the online magazine [Slate](/wiki/Slate_(magazine)) was one by [Atul Gawande](/wiki/Atul_Gawande) in which the required immunizations received by soldiers, including an [anthrax vaccination](/wiki/Anthrax_vaccines), were named as one of the likely culprits for the symptoms associated with the Gulf War Syndrome. In the late 1990s Slate published an article on the "brewing rebellion" in the military against anthrax immunization because of "the availability to soldiers of vaccine misinformation on the Internet". Slate continued to report on concerns about the required anthrax and [smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox) immunization for US troops after the [September 11 attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks) and articles on the subject also appeared on the [Salon](/wiki/Salon_(website)) website. [[115]](#cite_note-hausman-115) The [2001 anthrax attacks](/wiki/2001_anthrax_attacks) heightened concerns about [bioterrorism](/wiki/Bioterrorism) and the [Federal government of the United States](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States) stepped up its efforts to store and create more vaccines for American citizens. [[115]](#cite_note-hausman-115) In 2002, [Mother Jones](/wiki/Mother_Jones_(magazine)) published an article that was highly skeptical of the anthrax and smallpox immunization required by the [United States Armed Forces](/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces). [[115]](#cite_note-hausman-115) With the [2003 invasion of Iraq](/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq) a wider controversy ensued in the media about requiring US troops to be vaccinated against anthrax. [[115]](#cite_note-hausman-115) From 2003 to 2008 a series of court cases were brought to oppose the compulsory anthrax vaccination of US troops. [[131]](#cite_note-Edwards2016-131) This may lead to parental requests to space out vaccinations; however, studies have shown a child's stress response is not different when receiving one vaccination or two. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) Psychology The rise in vaccine hesitancy has led to research on the psychology of those who oppose vaccines. A 24-nation investigation led by the [University of Queensland](/wiki/University_of_Queensland) and reported in [Health Psychology](/wiki/Health_Psychology_(journal)) in 2018 found that the largest psychological factors leading to anti-vaccination attitudes were [conspiratorial thinking](/wiki/Conspiracy_theory), [reactance](/wiki/Reactance_(psychology)), disgust regarding blood or needles, and individualistic or hierarchical worldviews. In contrast, demographic variables were not significant. [[132]](#cite_note-132) Researchers have also investigated the psychological roots of vaccine hesitancy with regard to specific vaccines. For instance, a 2021 study published in [Nature Communications](/wiki/Nature_Communications) investigated psychological characteristics associated with COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy and resistance in Ireland and the UK. The study found that vaccine hesitant or resistant respondents in the two countries varied across socio-demographic and health-related variables, however, they were similar in range of psychological factors. Such respondents were less likely to obtain information about the pandemic from authoritative and traditional media sources and demonstrated similar skepticism towards these sources compared to respondents who accepted the vaccine. [[151]](#cite_note-151) Vaccine myths Several vaccination myths contribute to parental concerns and vaccine hesitancy. These include the alleged superiority of natural infection when compared to vaccination, questioning whether the diseases vaccines prevent are dangerous, whether vaccines pose moral or religious dilemmas, suggesting that vaccines are not effective, proposing unproven or ineffective approaches as alternatives to vaccines, and [conspiracy theories](/wiki/Conspiracy_theories) that center on mistrust of the government and medical institutions. [[29]](#cite_note-Jacobson2020-29) Autism The idea of a link between vaccines and autism has been extensively investigated and conclusively shown to be false. [[152]](#cite_note-152) [[153]](#cite_note-Smith2017-153) The [scientific consensus](/wiki/Scientific_consensus) is that there is no relationship, causal or otherwise, between vaccines and incidence of autism, [[50]](#cite_note-BH-50) [[154]](#cite_note-154) [[155]](#cite_note-155) and vaccine ingredients do not cause autism. [[156]](#cite_note-156) Nevertheless, the anti-vaccination movement continues to promote myths, [conspiracy theories](/wiki/Conspiracy_theory), and misinformation linking the two. [[157]](#cite_note-157) A developing tactic appears to be the "promotion of irrelevant research [as] an active aggregation of several questionable or peripherally related research studies in an attempt to justify the science underlying a questionable claim". [[158]](#cite_note-158) Vaccination during illness Many parents are concerned about the safety of vaccination when their child is sick. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) Moderate to severe acute illness with or without a fever is indeed a precaution when considering vaccination. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) Vaccines remain effective during childhood illness. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) The reason vaccines may be withheld if a child is moderately to severely ill is because certain expected side effects of vaccination (e.g. [fever](/wiki/Fever) or [rash](/wiki/Rash)) may be confused with the progression of the illness. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) It is safe to administer vaccines to well-appearing children who are mildly ill with the [common cold](/wiki/Common_cold). [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) Natural infection Another common anti-vaccine myth is that the [immune system](/wiki/Immune_system) produces a better immune protection in response to natural infection when compared to vaccination. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) However, strength and duration of immune protection gained varies by both disease and vaccine, with some vaccines giving better protection than natural infection. For example, the [HPV vaccine](/wiki/HPV_vaccine) generates better immune protection than natural infection due to the vaccine containing higher concentrations of a viral coat protein, while also not containing proteins the [HPV](/wiki/HPV) viruses use to inhibit immune response. [[159]](#cite_note-CNN_2020-10-20-159) While it is true that infection with certain illnesses may produce lifelong [immunity](/wiki/Immunity_(medical)), many natural infections do not produce lifelong immunity, while carrying a higher risk of harming a person's health than vaccines. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) For example, natural [varicella](/wiki/Varicella) infection carries a higher risk of bacterial superinfection with [Group A streptococci](/wiki/Group_A_streptococci). [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) Natural [measles](/wiki/Measles) infection carries a high risk of many serious, and sometimes life-long, complications, all of which can be avoided by vaccination. Those infected with measles rarely have a symptomatic reinfection. [[160]](#cite_note-160) Most people survive measles, though in some cases, complications may occur. Among those that experience complications, about 1 in 4 individuals will be hospitalized and 1-2 in 1000 will die. Complications are more likely in children under age 5 and adults over age 20. [[161]](#cite_note-161) [Pneumonia](/wiki/Pneumonia) is the most common fatal complication of measles infection and accounts for 56-86% of measles-related deaths. [[162]](#cite_note-162) Possible consequences of include [laryngotracheobronchitis](/wiki/Laryngotracheobronchitis), [sensorineural hearing loss](/wiki/Sensorineural_hearing_loss), [[163]](#cite_note-Cohen2014-163) and—in about 1 in 10,000 to 1 in 300,000 cases [[164]](#cite_note-Noyce2012-164)— [panencephalitis](/wiki/Subacute_sclerosing_panencephalitis), which is usually fatal. [[165]](#cite_note-ninds.nih.gov-165) Acute measles encephalitis is another serious risk of measles virus infection. It typically occurs two days to one week after the measles [rash](/wiki/Exanthem) breaks out and begins with very high fever, severe headache, [convulsions](/wiki/Convulsion) and altered mentation. A person with measles encephalitis may become [comatose](/wiki/Coma), and death or brain injury may occur. [[166]](#cite_note-166) The measles virus can deplete previously acquired [immune memory](/wiki/Immunological_memory) by killing cells that make antibodies, and thus weakens the immune system which can cause deaths from other diseases. [[167]](#cite_note-Amnesia-167) [[168]](#cite_note-Mina_2019-168) [[169]](#cite_note-Nature-169) [Suppression of the immune system](/wiki/Immunosuppression) by measles lasts about two years and has been epidemiologically implicated in up to 90% of childhood deaths in [third world](/wiki/Third_World) countries, and historically may have caused rather more deaths in the United States, the UK and Denmark than were directly caused by measles. [[170]](#cite_note-pmid25954009-170) Although the measles vaccine contains an attenuated strain, it does not deplete immune memory. [[168]](#cite_note-Mina_2019-168) HPV vaccine The idea that the [HPV vaccine](/wiki/HPV_vaccine) is linked to increased sexual behavior is not supported by scientific evidence. A review of nearly 1,400 adolescent girls found no difference in teen pregnancy, the incidence of [sexually transmitted infection](/wiki/Sexually_transmitted_infection), or [contraceptive](/wiki/Contraceptive) counseling regardless of whether they received the HPV vaccine. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) Thousands of Americans die each year from cancers preventable by the vaccine. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) There remains a disproportionate rate of HPV-related cancers amongst [LatinX](/wiki/Latinx) populations, leading researchers to explore how messaging may be made more effective to address vaccine hesitancy. [[171]](#cite_note-171) Vaccine schedule Other concerns have been raised about the vaccine schedule recommended by the [Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices](/wiki/Advisory_Committee_on_Immunization_Practices) (ACIP). The immunization schedule is designed to protect children against preventable diseases when they are most vulnerable. The practice of delaying or spacing out these vaccinations increases the amount of time the child is susceptible to these illnesses. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) Receiving vaccines on the schedule recommended by the ACIP is not linked to autism or developmental delay. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) Events following reductions in vaccination In several countries, reductions in the use of some vaccines were followed by increases in the diseases' morbidity and mortality. [[172]](#cite_note-Gangarosa_pertussis-172) [[173]](#cite_note-Allen_herd-173) According to the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention), continued high levels of vaccine coverage are necessary to prevent a resurgence of diseases that have been nearly eliminated. [[174]](#cite_note-CDC_stop-174) Pertussis remains a major health problem in developing countries, where mass vaccination is not practiced; the World Health Organization estimates it caused 294,000 deaths in 2002. [[175]](#cite_note-175) Vaccine hesitancy has contributed to the resurgence of preventable disease. For example, in 2019, the number of measles cases increased by thirty percent worldwide and many cases occurred in countries that had nearly eliminated measles. [[29]](#cite_note-Jacobson2020-29) Stockholm, smallpox (1873-74) An anti-vaccination campaign motivated by religious objections, concerns about effectiveness, and concerns about individual rights led to the vaccination rate in Stockholm dropping to just over 40%, compared to about 90% elsewhere in Sweden. A major smallpox [epidemic](/wiki/Epidemic) began there in 1873. It led to a rise in vaccine uptake and an end of the epidemic. [[176]](#cite_note-176) UK, pertussis (1970s-80s) In a 1974 report ascribing 36 reactions to [whooping cough](/wiki/Pertussis) (pertussis) vaccine, a prominent public-health academic claimed that the vaccine was only marginally effective and questioned whether its benefits outweigh its risks, and extended television and press coverage caused a scare. Vaccine uptake in the UK decreased from 81% to 31%, and pertussis epidemics followed, leading to the deaths of some children. The mainstream medical opinion continued to support the effectiveness and safety of the vaccine; public confidence was restored after the publication of a national reassessment of vaccine efficacy. Vaccine uptake then increased to levels above 90%, and disease incidence declined dramatically. [[172]](#cite_note-Gangarosa_pertussis-172) Sweden, pertussis (1979-96) In the vaccination moratorium period that occurred when Sweden suspended vaccination against whooping cough (pertussis) from 1979 to 1996, 60% of the country's children contracted the disease before the age of 10; close medical monitoring kept the death rate from whooping cough at about one per year. Three children died and several more were gravely ill, some requiring mechanical ventilation to recover. [[179]](#cite_note-179) Nigeria, polio, measles, diphtheria (2001-) In the early first decade of the 21st century, conservative religious leaders in northern Nigeria, suspicious of [Western medicine](/wiki/Medicine), advised their followers not to have their children vaccinated with the oral polio vaccine. The boycott was endorsed by the governor of Kano State, and immunization was suspended for several months. Subsequently, polio reappeared in a dozen formerly polio-free neighbors of Nigeria, and genetic tests showed the virus was the same one that originated in northern Nigeria. People in the northern states were also reported to be wary of other vaccinations, and Nigeria reported over 20,000 measles cases and nearly 600 deaths from measles from January through March 2005. [[217]](#cite_note-217) Samoa, measles (2019) The 2019 Samoa measles outbreak began in October 2019 and as of December 12, there were 4,995 confirmed cases of measles and 72 deaths, out of a Samoan population of 201,316. [[218]](#cite_note-218) [[219]](#cite_note-DeathToll-219) [[220]](#cite_note-220) [[221]](#cite_note-221) A state of emergency was declared on November 17, ordering all schools to be closed, barring children under 17 from public events, and making vaccination mandatory. [[222]](#cite_note-222) [UNICEF](/wiki/UNICEF) has sent 110,500 vaccines to Samoa. Tonga and Fiji have also declared states of emergency. [[223]](#cite_note-bbc-223) The outbreak has been attributed to a sharp drop in [measles vaccination](/wiki/Measles_vaccination) from the previous year, following an incident in 2018 when two infants died shortly after receiving measles vaccinations, which led the country to suspend its measles vaccination program. [[224]](#cite_note-TheGuardian-224) The reason for the two infants' deaths was incorrect preparation of the vaccine by two nurses who mixed vaccine powder with expired anesthetic. [[225]](#cite_note-nurse-225) As of November 30, more than 50,000 people were vaccinated by the government of Samoa. [[225]](#cite_note-nurse-225) 2019-2020 measles outbreaks Countermeasures Vaccine hesitancy is challenging and optimal strategies for approaching it remain uncertain. [[226]](#cite_note-Dubé2015-226) [[20]](#cite_note-Dubé-20) Multicomponent initiatives which include targeting undervaccinated populations, improving the convenience of and access to vaccines, educational initiatives, and mandates may improve vaccination uptake. [[227]](#cite_note-Brelsford2017-227) [[228]](#cite_note-Jarrett2015-228) The World Health Organization (WHO) published a paper in 2016 intending to aid experts on how to respond to vaccine deniers in public. The WHO recommends for experts to view the general public as their target audience rather than the vaccine denier when debating in a public forum. The WHO also suggests for experts to make unmasking the techniques that the vaccine denier uses to spread misinformation as the goal of the conversation. The WHO asserts that this will make the public audience more resilient against anti-vaccine tactics. [[229]](#cite_note-229) Providing information Many interventions designed to address vaccine hesitancy have been based on the [information deficit model](/wiki/Information_deficit_model). [[54]](#cite_note-McClure2017-54) This model assumes that vaccine hesitancy is due to a person lacking the necessary information and attempts to provide them with that information to solve the problem. [[54]](#cite_note-McClure2017-54) Despite many educational interventions attempting this approach, ample evidence indicates providing more information is often ineffective in changing a vaccine-hesitant person's views and may, in fact, have the opposite of the intended effect and reinforce their misconceptions. [[29]](#cite_note-Jacobson2020-29) [[54]](#cite_note-McClure2017-54) It is unclear whether interventions intended to educate parents about vaccines improve the rate of vaccination. [[227]](#cite_note-Brelsford2017-227) It is also unclear whether citing the reasons of benefit to others and [herd immunity](/wiki/Herd_immunity) improves parents' willingness to vaccinate their children. [[227]](#cite_note-Brelsford2017-227) In one trial, an educational intervention designed to dispel common misconceptions about the [influenza vaccine](/wiki/Influenza_vaccine) decreased parents' false beliefs about the vaccines but did not improve uptake of the influenza vaccine. [[227]](#cite_note-Brelsford2017-227) In fact, parents with significant concerns about adverse effects from the vaccine were less likely to vaccinate their children with the influenza vaccine after receiving this education. [[227]](#cite_note-Brelsford2017-227) Communication strategies Several communication strategies are recommended for use when interacting with vaccine-hesitant parents. These include establishing honest and respectful dialogue; acknowledging the risks of a vaccine but balancing them against the risk of disease; referring parents to reputable sources of vaccine information; and maintaining ongoing conversations with vaccine-hesitant families. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) The [American Academy of Pediatrics](/wiki/American_Academy_of_Pediatrics) recommends healthcare providers directly address parental concerns about vaccines when questioned about their efficacy and safety. [[131]](#cite_note-Edwards2016-131) Additional recommendations include asking permission to share information; maintaining a conversational tone (as opposed to lecturing); not spending excessive amounts of time debunking specific myths (this may have the opposite effect of strengthening the myth in the person's mind); focusing on the facts and simply identifying the myth as false; and keeping information as simple as possible (if the myth seems simpler than the truth, it may be easier for people to accept the simple myth). [[54]](#cite_note-McClure2017-54) Storytelling and anecdote (e.g., about the decision to vaccinate one's own children) can be powerful communication tools for conversations about the value of vaccination. [[54]](#cite_note-McClure2017-54) A New Zealand-based General Practitioner has used a comic, [Jenny & the Eddies](/wiki/Jenny_%26_the_Eddies), both to educate children about vaccines and address his patients' concerns through open, trusting, and non-threatening conversations, concluding [that] "I always listen to what people have to say on any matter. That includes vaccine hesitancy. That's a very important opening stage to improving the therapeutic relationship. If I'm going to change anyone's attitude, first I need to listen to them and be open-minded." [[230]](#cite_note-Using_books_to_help_in_NZ-230) The perceived strength of the recommendation, when provided by a healthcare provider, also seems to influence uptake, with recommendations that are perceived to be stronger resulting in higher vaccination rates than perceived weaker recommendations. [[29]](#cite_note-Jacobson2020-29) Provider presumption and persistence Limited evidence suggests that a more paternalistic or presumptive approach ("Your son needs three shots today.") is more likely to result in patient acceptance of vaccines during a clinic visit than a participatory approach ("What do you want to do about shots?") but decreases patient satisfaction with the visit. [[227]](#cite_note-Brelsford2017-227) A presumptive approach helps to establish that this is the normative choice. [[54]](#cite_note-McClure2017-54) Similarly, one study found that the way in which physicians respond to parental vaccine resistance is important. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) Nearly half of initially vaccine-resistant parents accepted vaccinations if physicians persisted in their initial recommendation. [[54]](#cite_note-McClure2017-54) The [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) has released resources to aid healthcare providers in having more effective conversations with parents about vaccinations. [[231]](#cite_note-CDCVaccineConversationResources-231) Pain mitigation for children Parents may be hesitant to have their children vaccinated due to concerns about the pain of vaccination. Several strategies can be used to reduce the child's pain. [[131]](#cite_note-Edwards2016-131) Such strategies include distraction techniques ( [pinwheels](/wiki/Pinwheel_(toy))); deep breathing techniques; [breastfeeding](/wiki/Breastfeeding) the child; giving the child sweet-tasting solutions; quickly administering the vaccine without aspirating; keeping the child upright; providing tactile stimulation; applying [numbing agents](/wiki/Anesthetic) to the skin; and saving the most painful vaccine for last. [[131]](#cite_note-Edwards2016-131) As above, the number of vaccines offered in a particular encounter is related to the likelihood of parental vaccine refusal (the more vaccines offered, the higher the likelihood of vaccine deferral). [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) The use of combination vaccines to protect against more diseases but with fewer injections may provide reassurance to parents. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) Similarly, reframing the conversation with less emphasis on the number of diseases the healthcare provider is immunizing against (e.g., "we will do two injections (combined vaccinations) and an oral vaccine") may be more acceptable to parents than "we're going to vaccinate against seven diseases". [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) Cultural sensitivity [Cultural sensitivity](/wiki/Cultural_sensitivity) is important to reducing vaccine hesitancy. For example, pollster [Frank Luntz](/wiki/Frank_Luntz) discovered that for [conservative Americans](/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_States), family is by far the "most powerful motivator" to get a vaccine (over country, economy, community, or friends). [[232]](#cite_note-Kenen-232) Luntz "also found a very pronounced preference for the word 'vaccine' over 'jab.'" [[232]](#cite_note-Kenen-232) Avoiding online misinformation It is recommended that healthcare providers advise parents against performing their own web search queries since many websites on the Internet contain significant misinformation. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) Many parents perform their own research online and are often confused, frustrated, and unsure of which sources of information are trustworthy. [[54]](#cite_note-McClure2017-54) Additional recommendations include introducing parents to the importance of vaccination as far in advance of the initial well-child visit as possible; presenting parents with vaccine safety information while in their pediatrician's waiting room; and using prenatal open houses and postpartum maternity ward visits as opportunities to vaccinate. [[2]](#cite_note-Smith2015-2) Internet advertising, especially on [social networking websites](/wiki/Advertising_on_social_networks), is purchased by both public health authorities and anti-vaccination groups. In the United States, the majority of anti-vaccine Facebook advertising in December 2018 and February 2019 had been paid for one of two groups: [Children's Health Defense](/wiki/Children%27s_Health_Defense) and [Stop Mandatory Vaccination](/wiki/Stop_Mandatory_Vaccination). The ads targeted women and young couples and generally highlighted the alleged risks of vaccines, while asking for donations. Several anti-vaccination advertising campaigns also targeted areas where measles outbreaks were underway during this period. The impact of Facebook's subsequent advertising policy changes has not been studied. [[233]](#cite_note-journ-233) [[234]](#cite_note-study-234) Incentive programs Several countries have implemented programs to counter vaccine hesitancy, including raffles, lotteries, rewards and mandates. [[235]](#cite_note-235) [[236]](#cite_note-236) [[237]](#cite_note-237) [[238]](#cite_note-238) In the US [State of Washington](/wiki/State_of_Washington), authorities have given the green light to licensed [cannabis dispensaries](/wiki/Cannabis_dispensaries) to offer free [joints](/wiki/Joint_(cannabis)) as incentives to get [COVID-19 vaccination](/wiki/COVID-19_vaccination) in an effort dubbed "Joints for Jabs". [[239]](#cite_note-239) Vaccine mandates Mandatory vaccination is one set of policy measures to address vaccine hesitancy by imposing penalties or burdens on those who fail to vaccinate. An example of this kind of measure is Australia's vaccine mandates around childhood vaccination, the [No Jab No Pay](/wiki/No_Jab_No_Pay) policy. This policy linked financial payments to children's vaccine status and, while studies have found significant improvements in vaccination compliance, years later there were still issues of vaccine hesitancy. [[240]](#cite_note-240) [[241]](#cite_note-241) In 2021, Australian airline [Qantas](/wiki/Qantas) issued plans to mandate [COVID-19 vaccination](/wiki/COVID-19_vaccination) for their work force. [[242]](#cite_note-242) History Variolation Early attempts to prevent smallpox involved deliberate [inoculation](/wiki/Inoculation) with the milder form of the disease (Variola Minor) in the expectation that a mild case would confer immunity and avoid Variola Major. Originally called inoculation, this technique was later called [variolation](/wiki/Variolation) to avoid confusion with cowpox inoculation ( [vaccination](/wiki/Vaccination)) when that was introduced by [Edward Jenner](/wiki/Edward_Jenner). Although variolation had a long history in China and India, it was first used in North America and England in 1721. [Reverend Cotton Mather](/wiki/Cotton_Mather) introduced variolation to Boston, Massachusetts, during the 1721 smallpox epidemic. [[243]](#cite_note-VaccineControversy-243) Despite strong opposition in the community, [[244]](#cite_note-Early-244) Mather convinced [Zabdiel Boylston](/wiki/Zabdiel_Boylston) to try it. Boylston first experimented on his 6-year-old son, his slave, and his slave's son; each subject contracted the disease and was sick for several days until the sickness vanished and they were "no longer gravely ill". [[243]](#cite_note-VaccineControversy-243) Boylston went on to variolate thousands of Massachusetts residents, and many places were named for him in gratitude as a result. [Lady Mary Wortley Montagu](/wiki/Lady_Mary_Wortley_Montagu) introduced variolation to England. She had seen it used in Turkey and, in 1718, had her son successfully variolated in Constantinople under the supervision of [Charles Maitland](/wiki/Charles_Maitland_(physician)). When she returned to England in 1721, she had her daughter variolated by Maitland. This aroused considerable interest, and Sir [Hans Sloane](/wiki/Hans_Sloane) organized the variolation of some inmates in [Newgate Prison](/wiki/Newgate_Prison). These were successful, and after a further short trial in 1722, two daughters of [Caroline of Ansbach](/wiki/Caroline_of_Ansbach) Princess of Wales were variolated without mishap. With this royal approval, the procedure became common when smallpox epidemics threatened. [[245]](#cite_note-williams-245) [Religious arguments against inoculation](/wiki/Vaccination_and_religion) were soon advanced. For example, in a 1722 sermon entitled "The Dangerous and Sinful Practice of Inoculation", the English theologian Reverend Edmund Massey argued that diseases are sent by God to punish sin and that any attempt to prevent smallpox via inoculation is a "diabolical operation". [[244]](#cite_note-Early-244) It was customary at the time for popular preachers to publish sermons, which reached a wide audience. This was the case with Massey, whose sermon reached North America, where there was early religious opposition, particularly by [John Williams](/wiki/John_Williams_(New_England_minister)). A greater source of opposition there was [William Douglass](/wiki/William_Douglass_(physician)), a medical graduate of [Edinburgh University](/wiki/Edinburgh_University) and a [Fellow of the Royal Society](/wiki/Fellow_of_the_Royal_Society), who had settled in Boston. [[245]](#cite_note-williams-245): 114-22 Smallpox vaccination [Edward Jenner](/wiki/Edward_Jenner) introduced the [smallpox vaccine](/wiki/Smallpox_vaccine) in 1798, variolation declined and was banned in some countries. [[246]](#cite_note-246) [[247]](#cite_note-247) As with variolation, there was some religious opposition to vaccination, although this was balanced to some extent by support from clergymen, such as Reverend Robert Ferryman, a friend of Jenner's, and [Rowland Hill](/wiki/Rowland_Hill_(preacher)), [[245]](#cite_note-williams-245): 221 who not only preached in its favour but also performed vaccination themselves. There was also opposition from some variolators who saw the loss of a lucrative monopoly. William Rowley published illustrations of deformities allegedly produced by vaccination, lampooned in [James Gillray](/wiki/James_Gillray)'s famous caricature depicted on this page, and [Benjamin Moseley](/wiki/Benjamin_Moseley) likened cowpox to [syphilis](/wiki/Syphilis), starting a controversy that would last into the 20th century. [[245]](#cite_note-williams-245): 203-05 There was legitimate concern from supporters of vaccination about its safety and efficacy, but this was overshadowed by general condemnation, particularly when legislation started to introduce compulsory vaccination. The reason for this was that vaccination was introduced before laboratory methods were developed to control its production and account for its failures. [[248]](#cite_note-baxby2001-248) Vaccine was maintained initially through arm-to-arm transfer and later through production on the skin of animals, and bacteriological sterility was impossible. Further, identification methods for potential pathogens were not available until the late 19th to early 20th century. Diseases later shown to be caused by contaminated vaccine included [erysipelas](/wiki/Erysipelas), [tuberculosis](/wiki/Tuberculosis), [tetanus](/wiki/Tetanus), and syphilis. This last, though rare - estimated at 750 cases in 100 million vaccinations [[249]](#cite_note-bazin2000-249) - attracted particular attention. Much later, [Charles Creighton](/wiki/Charles_Creighton_(physician)), a leading medical opponent of vaccination, claimed that the vaccine itself was a cause of syphilis and devoted a book to the subject. [[250]](#cite_note-creighton-250) As cases of smallpox started to occur in those who had been vaccinated earlier, supporters of vaccination pointed out that these were usually very mild and occurred years after the vaccination. In turn, opponents of vaccination pointed out that this contradicted Jenner's belief that vaccination conferred complete protection. [[248]](#cite_note-baxby2001-248): 17-21 The views of opponents of vaccination that it was both dangerous and ineffective led to the development of determined anti-vaccination movements in England when legislation was introduced to make vaccination compulsory. [[251]](#cite_note-williamson-251) England Because of its greater risks, [variolation](/wiki/Variolation) was banned in England by the 1840 [Vaccination Act](/wiki/Vaccination_Act), which also introduced free voluntary vaccination for infants. Thereafter Parliament passed successive acts to enact and enforce compulsory vaccination. [[252]](#cite_note-porter-252) The 1853 act introduced compulsory vaccination, with fines for non-compliance and imprisonment for non-payment. The 1867 act extended the age requirement to 14 years and introduced repeated fines for repeated refusal for the same child. Initially, vaccination regulations were organised by the local [Poor Law](/wiki/Poor_Law) Guardians, and in towns where there was strong opposition to vaccination, sympathetic Guardians were elected who did not pursue prosecutions. This was changed by the 1871 act, which required Guardians to act. This significantly changed the relationship between the government and the public, and organized protests increased. [[252]](#cite_note-porter-252) In Keighley, Yorkshire, in 1876 the Guardians were arrested and briefly imprisoned in York Castle, prompting large demonstrations in support of the "Keighley Seven". [[251]](#cite_note-williamson-251): 108-09 The protest movements crossed social boundaries. The financial burden of fines fell hardest on the working class, who would provide the largest numbers at public demonstrations. [[253]](#cite_note-253) Societies and publications were organized by the middle classes, and support came from celebrities such as [George Bernard Shaw](/wiki/George_Bernard_Shaw) and [Alfred Russel Wallace](/wiki/Alfred_Russel_Wallace), doctors such as Picton](/wiki/James_Allanson_Picton). [[252]](#cite_note-porter-252) By 1885, with over 3,000 prosecutions pending in [Leicester](/wiki/Leicester), a mass rally there was attended by over 20,000 protesters. [[254]](#cite_note-baxby1999-254) Under increasing pressure, the government appointed a Royal Commission on Vaccination in 1889, which issued six reports between 1892 and 1896, with a detailed summary in 1898. [[255]](#cite_note-255) Its recommendations were incorporated into the 1898 Vaccination Act, which still required compulsory vaccination but allowed exemption on the grounds of conscientious objection on presentation of a certificate signed by two magistrates. [[11]](#cite_note-wolfesharp-11) [[252]](#cite_note-porter-252) These were not easy to obtain in towns where magistrates supported compulsory vaccination, and after continued protests, a further act in 1907 allowed exemption on a simple signed declaration. [[254]](#cite_note-baxby1999-254) Although this solved the immediate problem, the compulsory vaccination acts remained legally enforceable, and determined opponents lobbied for their repeal. No Compulsory Vaccination was one of the demands of the [1900 Labour Party General Election Manifesto](/wiki/1900_United_Kingdom_general_election). [[256]](#cite_note-256) This was done as a matter of routine when the [National Health Service](/wiki/National_Health_Service) was introduced in 1948, with "almost negligible" opposition from supporters of compulsory vaccination. [[257]](#cite_note-millard1948-257) Vaccination in Wales was covered by English legislation, but the [Scottish legal system](/wiki/Scottish_legal_system) was separate. Vaccination was not made compulsory there until 1863, and a conscientious objection was allowed after vigorous protest only in 1907. [[248]](#cite_note-baxby2001-248): 10-11 In the late 19th century, Leicester in the UK received much attention because of how smallpox was managed there. There was particularly strong opposition to compulsory vaccination, and medical authorities had to work within this framework. They developed a system that did not use vaccination but was based on the notification of cases, the strict isolation of patients and contacts, and the provision of isolation hospitals. [[258]](#cite_note-258) This proved successful but required acceptance of compulsory isolation rather than vaccination. [C. Killick Millard](/wiki/C._Killick_Millard), initially, a supporter of compulsory vaccination was appointed [Medical Officer of Health](/wiki/Medical_Officer_of_Health) in 1901. He moderated his views on compulsion but encouraged contacts and his staff to accept vaccination. This approach, developed initially due to overwhelming opposition to government policy, became known as the Leicester Method. [[257]](#cite_note-millard1948-257) [[259]](#cite_note-fraser-259) In time it became generally accepted as the most appropriate way to deal with smallpox outbreaks and was listed as one of the "important events in the history of smallpox control" by those most involved in the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization)'s successful [Smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox) Eradication Campaign. The final stages of the campaign generally referred to as "surveillance containment", owed much to the Leicester method. [[260]](#cite_note-260) [[261]](#cite_note-261) United States In the US, President [Thomas Jefferson](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson) took a close interest in vaccination, alongside [Benjamin Waterhouse](/wiki/Benjamin_Waterhouse), chief physician at Boston. Jefferson encouraged the development of ways to transport vaccine material through the Southern states, which included measures to avoid damage by heat, a leading cause of ineffective batches. [Smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox) outbreaks were contained by the latter half of the 19th century, a development widely attributed to the vaccination of a large portion of the population. Vaccination rates fell after this decline in smallpox cases, and the disease again became epidemic in the late 19th century. [[262]](#cite_note-262) After an 1879 visit to New York by prominent British anti-vaccinationist [William Tebb](/wiki/William_Tebb), The Anti-Vaccination Society of America was founded. [[263]](#cite_note-263) [[264]](#cite_note-history-264) The New England Anti-Compulsory Vaccination League formed in 1882, and the Anti-Vaccination League of New York City in 1885. [[264]](#cite_note-history-264) Tactics in the US largely followed those used in England. [[265]](#cite_note-265) Vaccination in the US was regulated by individual states, in which there followed a progression of compulsion, opposition, and repeal similar to that in England. [[266]](#cite_note-266) Although generally organized on a state-by-state basis, the vaccination controversy reached the [US Supreme Court](/wiki/US_Supreme_Court) in 1905. There, in the case of [Jacobson v. Massachusetts](/wiki/Jacobson_v._Massachusetts), the court ruled that states have the authority to require vaccination against smallpox during a smallpox epidemic. [[267]](#cite_note-267) [John Pitcairn](/wiki/John_Pitcairn,_Jr.), the wealthy founder of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company (now [PPG Industries](/wiki/PPG_Industries)), emerged as a major financier and leader of the American anti-vaccination movement. On March 5, 1907, in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, he delivered an address to the Committee on Public Health and Sanitation of the [Pennsylvania General Assembly](/wiki/Pennsylvania_General_Assembly) criticizing vaccination. [[268]](#cite_note-vaccination_address-268) He later sponsored the National Anti-Vaccination Conference, which, held in Philadelphia in October 1908, led to the creation of The Anti-Vaccination League of America. When the league organized later that month, members chose Pitcairn as their first president. [[269]](#cite_note-Horrors-269) On December 1, 1911, Pitcairn was appointed by Pennsylvania Governor [John K. Tener](/wiki/John_K._Tener) to the Pennsylvania State Vaccination Commission and subsequently authored a detailed report strongly opposing the commission's conclusions. [[269]](#cite_note-Horrors-269) He remained a staunch opponent of vaccination until his death in 1916. Brazil In November 1904, in response to years of inadequate sanitation and disease, followed by a poorly explained public health campaign led by the renowned Brazilian public health official [Oswaldo Cruz](/wiki/Oswaldo_Cruz), citizens and military cadets in Rio de Janeiro arose in a Revolta da Vacina, or [Vaccine Revolt](/wiki/Vaccine_Revolt). Riots broke out on the day a vaccination law took effect; vaccination symbolized the most feared and most tangible aspect of a public health plan that included other features, such as urban renewal, that many had opposed for years. [[270]](#cite_note-270) Later vaccines and antitoxins Opposition to smallpox vaccination continued into the 20th century and was joined by controversy over new vaccines and the introduction of [antitoxin](/wiki/Antitoxin) treatment for [diphtheria](/wiki/Diphtheria). Injection of horse serum into humans as used in antitoxin can cause [hypersensitivity](/wiki/Hypersensitivity), commonly referred to as [serum sickness](/wiki/Serum_sickness). Moreover, the continued production of the smallpox vaccine in animals and the production of antitoxins in horses prompted [anti-vivisectionists](/wiki/Anti-vivisectionist) to oppose vaccination. [[271]](#cite_note-271) Diphtheria antitoxin was serum from horses that had been immunized against diphtheria, and was used to treat human cases by providing [passive immunity](/wiki/Passive_immunity). In 1901, antitoxin from a horse named [Jim](/wiki/Jim_(horse)) was contaminated with [tetanus](/wiki/Tetanus) and killed 13 children in [St. Louis](/wiki/St._Louis), Missouri. This incident, together with nine deaths from tetanus from contaminated smallpox vaccine in [Camden, New Jersey](/wiki/Camden,_New_Jersey), led directly and quickly to the passing of the [Biologics Control Act](/wiki/Biologics_Control_Act) in 1902. [[272]](#cite_note-272) The [Bundaberg tragedy](/wiki/Bundaberg_tragedy) of saw a diphtheria antitoxin contaminated with the [Staph. aureus](/wiki/Staph._aureus) bacterium kill 12 children in [Bundaberg](/wiki/Bundaberg), Australia, resulting in the suspension of local immunisation programs. [[273]](#cite_note-273) [Robert Koch](/wiki/Robert_Koch) developed [tuberculin](/wiki/Tuberculin) in 1890. Inoculated individuals who have had [tuberculosis](/wiki/Tuberculosis), it produces a [hypersensitivity](/wiki/Hypersensitivity) reaction and is still used to detect those who have been infected. However, Koch used tuberculin as a vaccine. This caused serious reactions and deaths in individuals whose latent tuberculosis was reactivated by the tuberculin. [[274]](#cite_note-274) This was a major setback for supporters of new vaccines. [[248]](#cite_note-baxby2001-248): 30-31 Such incidents and others ensured that any untoward results concerning vaccination and related procedures received continued publicity, which grew as the number of new procedures increased. [[275]](#cite_note-275) In 1955, in a tragedy known as the [Cutter incident](/wiki/Cutter_incident), [Cutter Laboratories](/wiki/Cutter_Laboratories) produced 120,000 doses of the [Salk polio vaccine](/wiki/Salk_polio_vaccine) that inadvertently contained some live poliovirus along with inactivated virus. This vaccine caused 40,000 cases of polio, 53 cases of paralysis, and five deaths. The disease spread through the recipients' families, creating a polio epidemic that led to a further 113 cases of [paralytic polio](/wiki/Paralytic_polio) and another five deaths. It was one of the worst pharmaceutical disasters in US history. [[276]](#cite_note-276) Later 20th-century events included the 1982 broadcast of DPT: Vaccine Roulette, which sparked debate over the [DPT vaccine](/wiki/DPT_vaccine), [[277]](#cite_note-277) and the 1998 publication of a fraudulent academic article by [Andrew Wakefield](/wiki/Andrew_Wakefield) [[278]](#cite_note-Goldacre-2008-278) which sparked the [MMR vaccine controversy](/wiki/MMR_vaccine_controversy). Also recently, the [HPV vaccine](/wiki/HPV_vaccine) has become controversial due to concerns that it may encourage promiscuity when given to 11- and 12-year-old girls. [[279]](#cite_note-279) [[280]](#cite_note-280) Arguments against vaccines in the 21st century are often similar to those of 19th-century anti-vaccinationists. [[11]](#cite_note-wolfesharp-11) Around 2014, anti-vaccine rhetoric shifted from being mostly scientific and medical arguments, such as the idea that vaccines were harming children, to political arguments, such as what David Broniatowski of [George Washington University](/wiki/George_Washington_University) has called a "don't-tell-me-what-to-do freedom movement." At the same time, according to [Renée DiResta](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9e_DiResta), a researcher at the [Stanford Internet networking with in a "weird [libertarian](/wiki/Libertarianism) crossover". This happened partly due to anti-vaccine medical arguments failing to stop the passage of [SB277](/wiki/California_Senate_Bill_277) in California. [[281]](#cite_note-:8-281) COVID-19 In mid-2020, surveys on whether people would be willing to take a potential [COVID-19 vaccine](/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine) estimated that 67% or 80% of people in the US would accept a new vaccination against COVID-19. [[282]](#cite_note-malik-282) [[283]](#cite_note-283) In the United Kingdom, a 16 November 2020 [YouGov](/wiki/YouGov) poll showed that 42% said they were very likely to take the vaccine and 25% were fairly likely (67% likely overall); 11% would be very unlikely and 10% fairly unlikely (21% unlikely overall) and 12% are unsure. [[131]](#cite_note-Edwards2016-131) Individual liberty Compulsory vaccination policies have been controversial as long as they have existed, with opponents of mandatory vaccinations arguing that governments should not infringe on an individual's freedom to make medical decisions for themselves or their children, while proponents of compulsory vaccination cite the well-documented public health benefits of vaccination. [[342]](#cite_note-:0-342) Spanish-American War The [Spanish-American War](/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War) began in April 1898 and ended in August 1898.
